title: Robert Williams (adjutant general)
text:
Robert Williams (November 5, 1829–August 24, 1901) was an officer in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> who served as <a href="List%20of%20Adjutant%20Generals%20of%20the%20U.S.%20Army">Adjutant General of the U.S. Army</a> from 1892 to 1893.
Biography.
He was born in <a href="Culpeper%20County%2C%20Virginia">Culpeper County, Virginia</a> and graduated from the <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">United States Military Academy</a> in 1851. He was appointed to the <a href="1st%20Cavalry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">1st Dragoons</a>, in which he served until the outbreak of the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. He served in various staff positions at the beginning of the war, before becoming <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> of <a href="1st%20Massachusetts%20Volunteer%20Cavalry">1st Massachusetts Volunteer Cavalry</a> in October 1861. He resigned his Volunteer commission in October 1862 and became a <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> in the Adjutant General's Department.
Williams remained in the Adjutant General's Department following the end of the war, and was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> in February 1869. He was served as adjutant general of the <a href="Department%20of%20the%20Missouri%23Indian%20Wars">Department of the Missouri</a>, the <a href="Department%20of%20the%20Platte">Department of the Platte</a>, and the <a href="Department%20of%20the%20Missouri%23Indian%20Wars">Division of the Missouri</a>, earning a promotion to colonel in July 1881. In December 1890 he returned to the Adjutant General's Department in Washington, and he was elevated to Adjutant General of the U. S. Army with the rank of <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> in July 1892. He retired in November 1893.
He died in August 1901, and is buried in <a href="Arlington%20National%20Cemetery">Arlington National Cemetery</a>.
